Wuhan University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430081 China In this study, Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized by reflux-coprecipitation method, and then these catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, SEM and TEM. Meanwhile, the toluene removal and secondary pollutants in a nonthermal plasma coupled with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 reactor were studied, and then the reaction kinetic model and reaction pathway for the toluene removal were proposed. The results indicated that positive synergistic effect between the plasma and Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts greatly improved the removal performance, and reduced secondary pollutants and activation energy during toluene removal process in the plasma packed with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 system. Meanwhile, the plasma packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/Al2O3 exhibited the highest removal efficiency (98.59%) and CO2 selectivity (88.02%) with the lowest secondary pollutants and activation energy during toluene removal under the SED of 1500 J/L and the GHSV of 80,000 ml g − 1 h − 1. Finally, the toluene removal pathway in the plasma-catalysis system was also discussed based on the identified intermediates and synergistic effect between the plasma and Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Toluene Non-thermal plasma Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 Removal mechanism 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are the main precursors of PM2.5 and O3 formation that regarded as one of the main pollutants to the atmosphere due to it causes photochemical smog, ozone depletion, and global warming [1,2]. VOCs are mainly emitted from industrial sources, biogenic sources and mobile sources [3]. Among them, industrial source VOCs generated from chemical, petrochemical, and pharmaceuticals industry that is the main contributor for the VOCs emission. It was reported that china emitted 21.13 million tons of industrial source VOCs in 2020, which accounted for 55% of the total VOCs emission [4]. Generally, the aromatic VOCs such as benzene, toluene, o-xylene are the main components for the industrial source VOCs that exhibited higher toxicity to human health and major environmental concerns due to their potential carcinogenic, teratogenic, and mutagenic effects [5]. Therefore, it is urgently required to develop a high-efficiency and low energy consumption technology for VOCs control. At present, conventional treatment methods, including adsorption-condensation, catalytic oxidation, thermal combustion, plasma oxidation, and biotechnology, are used to control the VOCs emission [6]. Catalytic oxidation is widely used for VOCs removal due to it converts the VOCs into CO2 and H2O at moderate temperature range of 200−550 °C [7]. However, the structure of the benzene ring and the intermediates are readily adsorbed on the active sites during the aromatic VOCs removal process and thus resulted in deactivation of catalysts [8,9]. Meanwhile, the temperatures range of 200−550 °C are required to activate the catalyst when the catalytic oxidation is used to treat the aromatic VOCs such as benzene, toluene, o-xylene, etc., suggesting that a large amount of energy is necessary to preheat the exhaust gas [10]. Nonthermal plasma can treat the exhaust gas at room temperature since it produces various active free radicals that can be used to oxidate VOCs. Whereas the nonthermal plasma exhibited a poor selectivity toward CO2 and higher secondary pollution such as NOx and O3, which limited its wide application [11]. Nonthermal plasma coupled with catalytic technology (called as plasma-catalysis) is regarded as one of the most promising approaches for the removal of aromatic VOCs [12]. Compared to the plasma and catalytic oxidation, the plasma-catalysis process is more powerful for VOCs degradation due to it combines the advantages between plasma and catalytic oxidation technology [13]. One is that the plasma activates the VOCs molecules and then produces active free radicals for oxidative reactions over the surface of catalysts, resulted in higher activity for VOCs degradation at room temperature [14]. Another is that the presence of catalysts in plasma-catalysis reactor can effectively promote the aromatic VOCs selectively conversion to CO2 and suppress the NOx and O3 formation [15]. The last one is that the positive synergistic between the plasma and catalysts greatly suppress the adsorption of VOC molecules and the intermediates on the surface of the catalysts, favoring the self-regeneration of catalyst and thus keeping the high stability during aromatic VOCs degradation process [16]. In addition to the reaction conditions such as specific energy density (SED), relative humidity, space velocity and residence time, catalysts such as the active catalytic species and supports are also significant for the VOCs removal in the plasma-catalysis system. Jiang et al. [17] studied three supports of SiO2, ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 loading with Mn, Co, Fe and Cu were used to remove toluene in a plasma-catalysis system, and found that Mn/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the highest toluene oxidation performance due to it catalyzed the toluene to carbonate and bicarbonate via the breakage of CC bonds from benzoic acid. Dang et al. [18]. and Huang et al. [19]. used different metals (Cu, Au, Ag, and Co) supported on γ-Al2O3 to remove toluene in a plasma-catalysis reactor, and claimed that the Au/Al2O3 exhibited excellent catalytic performance. Yao et al. [20]. also found that the toluene removal efficiency was 45.3% at an SED of 26.4 J/L in a plasma-catalysis reactor packed with CeO2/Al2O3. Zhu et al. [14,21] reported that the toluene conversion and CO2 selectivity were in sequence as 93% and 71% at SED of 1800 J/L in a plasma-catalysis reactor filled with Ag/CeO2/Al2O3, and the toluene conversion and CO2 selectivity were enhanced to 99% and 90% CO2 at SED of 1500 J/L when the plasma-catalysis reactor packed with Au/CeO2/Al2O3. Fe-Mn/Al2O3 exhibited excellent activity and high stability for toluene catalytic oxidation at 250−300 °C due to a strong interaction between Fe and Mn [22]. However, few studies on toluene removal in the plasma-catalysis system packed with Fe-Mn/Al2O3 had been reported. In this study, Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized by the reflux- coprecipitation method. The catalysts were analyized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, SEM and TEM, and then the toluene removal over Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was studied in a nonthermal plasma-catalysis reactor. Meanwhile, the effects of initial toluene concentration, residence time and relative humidity on the toluene removal efficiency and secondary pollutants were investigated, and the kinetic for toluene removal in a nonthermal plasma packed with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 reactor was obtained. Finally, a toluene removal pathway in the plasma-catalysis system based on the identified intermediates was also proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Fex−Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts In this study, Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized by reflux-coprecipitation method. In briefly, Al(NO3)3•9H2O was used as the precursor for Al2O3 carrier preparation. Fe(NO3)3•9H2O and Mn(NO3)2 were used as active components. The solution formed from the stoichiometric amount of Fe(NO3)3•9H2O, Mn(NO3)2 and Al(NO3)3•9H2O were distilled in 100 mL double water and stirred at 40 °C for 1 h. NaOH was used as the precipitant to control the slurry at pH=11±0.05. Afterwards, the slurry was moved into a round bottom flask and refluxed to crystallize with stirring of 800 rpm at 80 °C for 24 h. After crystallization, the catalysts were washed and dried at 110 °C, and then calcining at 400 °C for 2 h. Finally, the 40−60 mesh catalyst was prepared by grounding and sieving. The mass percentage of Fe and Mn in these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were 10 wt.%, and x/y was defined as the mole percentage of Fe and Mn in these catalysts. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Automated adsorption analyzer (BET, Micromeritics ASAP 2020), X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Dmax/2400), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR, Quanta chrome Instruments), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS, AXIS ULTRADLD), and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOLJEM-2100) were used to characterize these catalysts. The textural properties of these catalysts were measured by the BET. The crystal structures of these catalysts were characterized by a XRD with CuKa radiation at a scanning rate of 10 o/min over the 2θ range of 10–90 o. H2-TPR was carried out on a micromeritics Chem star™. The surface compositions of these catalysts were tested by the XPS with Al Ka radiation at 150 W. The morphologies of these catalysts were determined by the SEM and TEM. 2.3 Plasma-catalysis test The experiments were conducted in a homemade dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) system packed with these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1 . The experimental equipment consisted of a homemade DBD reactor, a gas supply system and gas measuring system. The DBD reactor comprised a typical wire-in-tube structure, as detail described in our previous paper [23]. 0.15 g of catalysts were loaded into the DBD reactor to comprise the plasma-catalysis system. The gas supply system was used to produce the simulated flue gas that consisted of nitrogen, oxygen, VOCs and steam. The VOCs was supplied by an injection pump and an evaporator (FD-PG, Suzhou, China), and the relative humidity (RH) of the stimulated flue gas was controlled by injecting the water using a plug pump. In order to determine the performance of the plasma-catalysis system, 200 mL/min stimulated flue gas (20% O2 balance N2) with the toluene concentration of 500−1000 ppm was introduced into the DBD reactor at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 80,000 ml g − 1h−1. The gas measuring system consisted of a gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7820A), a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Agilent 7820A-5977B, USA), a FTIR (Bruker Tensor II, German), an ozone monitor (2 B Technologies, Model 106 L, USA) and a NOx analyzer (Thermal 42i). The content of the toluene in the stimulated flue gas was detected by the GC equipped with FID detector (molecular sieve-packed column), and the GC coupled with a TCD detector (PoraBOND Q column) was used to detect CO2 and CO in the exhausted gas. The organic compounds in the exhausted gas was firstly detected by the FTIR at 4000−1000 cm−1 with a resolution of 0.5 cm−1, combined with a 5.0 m gas cell, and then the GC coupled with a FID and a MS was used to quantitatively measure the organic compounds separated by a HP-PLOT Al2O3 column and a DB–624 column. The quantification method of organic compounds in the exhaust gas was detailly described in our previous study [24,25]. The contents of O3 and NOx were detected by the ozone monitor and NOx analyzer. In addition, the in-situ FTIR was used to investigate the occurrence of intermediate products during the reaction process. The spectra was recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 for each spectrum. The toluene removal efficiency and CO2 selectivity are calculated according to the Eq. (1) and Eq. (2): (1) X T = C in Toluene − C o u t T o l u e n e C i n T o l u e n e × 100 % (2) X C O 2 = C o u t C O 2 7 × ( C i n T o l u e n e − C o u t T o l u e n e × 100 % Where X T refers to the toluene removal efficiency (%); X C O 2 is the CO2 selectivity (%); while C i n T o l u e n e and C o u t T o l u e n e refer to the inlet and outlet mass concentration of toluene, respectively; C o u t C O 2 is the outlet CO2 concentration. (3) S E D = P F × 60 Where SED defines as specific energy density (J/L), which was calculated by Eq. (3); P is discharge power (W); F is the gas flow rate (ml/min). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis of catalysts The textural properties of these catalysts were shown in Fig. S1 and Table 1 . It could be seen that the BET surface area and pore volume of the Mn/γ-Al2O3 were 355.00 m2/g and 0.42 cm3/g, respectively. As for the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the BET surface area and pore volume were in sequence as 390.30 m2/g and 0.33 cm3/g. As the Fe/Mn ratio was varied from 3:1 to 1:3, the BET surface areas of these Fex−Mny/γ-Al2O3 gradually decreased from 388.7 to 336.6 m2/g, while the pore volume firstly increased and then decreased, and the maximum pore volume was obtained for Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 (0.49 cm3/g). Our previous study reported that the BET surface area, pore volume and pore size of the Fex−Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared by an incipient wet-impregnation method were in sequence as 106.45 m2/g, 0.1760 cm3 /g and 66.16 nm [4]. The above results indicated that the refluxing-coprecipitation to synthesize Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 was able to enhance the homogeneous distribution of Fe and Mn species over the γ-Al2O3, resulting in increase of the BET surface area of the catalyst [18]. Moreover, it was also found that the pore sizes of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were range of 1 − 2 nm, which favored for the adsorption and transformation of toluene molecules and its intermediates over the Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts [14]. It was well known that the larger of the BET surface area indicated that the catalyst processed more active sites [2,23]. Meanwhile, the larger pore volume indicated that VOCs was more conducive to diffused and adsorption on the surface of catalyst [26,27]. Generally, the larger amount of micropore (< 2 nm) was benefitable to diffused and adsorption of benzene ring since the micropore matched the kinetic diameter of benzene ring [22]. Fig. 2 presented the X-ray diffraction patterns of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Several sharp diffraction peaks located at 37.6 °, 45.9 °, 64.7 ° and 67.0 ° were assigned to γ-Al2O3 on the surface of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 (PDF#10–0425). As for the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, the diffraction peaks attributing to a-FeOx were observed at 24.2 °, 33.4 °, 35.7 °, 41.2 °, 49.9 °, 54.4 °, 62.87 °, 72.1 ° and 75.9 ° (PDF# 33–0664). Moreover, the diffraction peaks corresponding to MnO2 (36.3 °, 42.4 °, 56.5 ° and 66.8 °) (PDF#30–0820) and Mn2O3 (33.5 °, 57.2 ° and 61.0 °) (PDF#65–7467) were detected on the surface of the Mn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. However, there was no visible phases of Fe and Mn observed on the surface of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The above results indicated that the distributions of Fe and Mn on the surface of γ-Al2O3 were amorphous, inferring that the interaction between Fe and Mn favored the homogeneous distribution of Fe and Mn, and resulted in inhibiting the crystallization of Fe and Mn [10]. The high dispersion and amorphous Fe and Mn over the Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts may exhibit better performance for the VOCs oxidation [4,28]. Fig. 3 displayed the SEM and TEM images of the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. It was observed in Fig. 3(a) that the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 exhibited a block morphology with rough surface and porous structure. The particle of the catalyst was 1–3 μm accompanying with some small pieces. From Fig. 3(b), It could be seen that there were many cracks formed on the block structure due to the mesopores generated during calcination. Fig. 3(c-e) showed the TEM images of the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. It was reported that the mesoporous structure was more conducive to the occurrence of lattice defects and increase of BET surface area [20,22]. It was also observed that the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst mainly comprised two planes (Fig. 3(f)), attributing to (111) and (110) planes of γ-Fe2O3 phase with their interplanar spacing of 0.167 nm and 0.216 nm. Meanwhile, there was no observation of lattice fringe for MnO2 due to the Mn incorporation into γ-Al2O3, and the MnO2 phase highly dispersed on γ-Al2O3, proved by the XRD results [18]. 3.2 Redox properties and surface composition of catalysts In order to investigate the redox performance of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, H2-TPR analysis was performed, as shown in Fig. 4 . Previous investigation found that the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 happened at 396 °C, Fe3O4 to FeO at 660 °C and FeO to Feo at 720 °C over the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [29]. In case of the Mn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 took place at 302 °C, Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 at 389 °C and Mn3O4 to MnO at 697 °C [4,10]. The reduction peaks of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts appeared at 235–325 °C and 350–434 °C, attributing to the stepwise reduction of Fe-Mn composite oxide. The above observation was consistent with the previous investigations that the reduction of mixed transition metal oxides underwent a distinct stepwise process, such as Fe-Mn, Mn-Ce, Co-Mn oxides [3,4,13,14,19,30-36]. Generally, the peaks between 235 and 325 °C should be assigned to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3. Notably, the reduction of low-temperature oxygen species in these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was much easier than that in Mn/γ-Al2O3 (302 °C), indicating that the reflux-coprecipitation method caused a strong interaction between Fe and Mn species [37]. The peaks at 325–434 °C attributed to the successive transformation such as Mn2O3 to MnO and Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Compared with the Mn/γ-Al2O3 and Fe/γ-Al2O3, the reduction of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts shifted to lower temperature region. The above result was mainly attributed to a strong interaction between Fe and Mn, which enhanced the mobility of oxygen species, resulted in improving the redox performance of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts [4,10,22]. The H2 consumption was also listed in Table 1. It can be observed that the H2 consumption of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts followed in the order of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe2 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn2/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn3/γ-Al2O3 > Fe3 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Mn/γ-Al2O3 > Fe/γ-Al2O3, indicating that the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 was more easily reduced by H2 than other catalysts. There were two reasons that caused the above phenomena: one was that the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 given more lattice oxygen compared with the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn/γ-Al2O3 catalysts [22]; another was that more active component migrated from the bulk to the surface of the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [4,10]. XPS analysis was employed to investigate the elemental composition on the surface of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5 and Table 1. Fig. 5(a) indicated the Fe 2p region contained two main spin-orbital lines; the 2p3/2 peak located at 710.5 eV was assigned to the Fe2+, whereas the Fe 2p3/2 signal centered at 714.2 eV together with the shakeup satellites at 719.1 eV was belonged to Fe3+. The Mn 2p peaks also comprised two main spin-orbital lines. The Mn 2p3/2 at 641.7 eV was attributed to surface Mn3+ or Mn2+, whereas the Mn 2p3/2 at 643.3 eV was assigned to Mn4+. The O 1 s spectra had two distinct peaks, one located at 529.8 eV was corresponded to lattice oxygen (Olatt), another peak located at 530.8 eV was ascribed to surface adsorbed oxygen with low coordination situation (Oads). Table 1 listed the surface compositions calculated from the XPS spectra of these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The Fe3+/(Fe2++ Fe3+) ratio and the Mn4+/(Mn2++ Mn3++ Mn4+) ratio in these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts followed the order of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn2/γ-Al2O3 > Fe2 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn3/γ-Al2O3 > Fe3 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3, indicating that the reduction performance of the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 was more excellent compared with other catalysts. Meanwhile, it was also found that the corresponding ratios of Olatt/(Oads+Olatt) were in sequence as 36.65%, 36.43%, 33.18%, 33.16%, 34.51%, 32.67% and 34.15% for the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3, Fe2 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3, Fe1 −Mn2/γ-Al2O3, Fe1 −Mn3/γ-Al2O3, Fe3 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3, Mn/γ-Al2O3 and Fe/γ-Al2O3, inferring that the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 contained more lattice oxygen compared with other catalysts. In the Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, valence transition between Fe2+ and Fe3+ acts as an oxygen donator for the transformation and storage of oxygen, and the variation between Mn3+ and Mn4+ diverts oxygen species to the surface of the Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts according to the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [10,28]. Meanwhile, the interactions between MnOx and FeOx can enhance the oxygen mobility on the catalysts and accelerate the formation of active oxygen species [4,9]. 3.3 Toluene removal activity and stability by the plasma-catalysis system In this study, a plasma-catalysis system packed with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was applied to the toluene removal. Fig. 6 illustrated that the toluene removal efficiency by the plasma alone was only 13%–62% with CO2 selectivity of 25%–65% when the SED increased from 300 to 1500 J/L due to the reactions between toluene molecules and active species and energetic electrons in plasma [7]. Fig.S2 also indicated that enhancing the SED could produce more active species, and then increase the toluene removal efficiency. Nevertheless, the higher toluene oxidation performance was difficult to be achieved through the homogeneous reactions in gas phase, thus resulted in lower toluene removal efficiency and CO2 selectivity. At the same SED, coupling plasma with the Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts achieved a higher toluene removal efficiency and CO2 selectivity compared with the plasma alone. The removal efficiency of toluene in the plasma packed with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with different Fe/Mn ratio followed the order of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn2/γ-Al2O3 > Fe2 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn3/γ-Al2O3 > Fe3 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Mn/γ-Al2O3 > Fe/γ-Al2O3. However, the CO2 selectivity for the toluene removal in the plasma packed with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with different Fe/Mn ratio followed the order of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe3 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn2/γ-Al2O3 > Fe1 −Mn3/γ-Al2O3 > Fe2 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 > Mn/γ-Al2O3 > Fe/γ-Al2O3. The above results indicated that the toluene removal efficiency in the plasma packed with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with different Fe/Mn ratio exhibited the same order with the Fe3+/(Fe2++ Fe3+) ratio and the Mn4+/(Mn2++ Mn3++ Mn4+) ratio in these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Meanwhile, it also can be found that the plasma-catalysis system packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the highest toluene removal efficiency and CO2 selectivity owing to the excellent catalytic activity of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6, the plasma-catalysis system packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 achieved 98.59% of toluene removal efficiency and 88.02% of CO2 selectivity under the SED of 1500 J/L. This suggested that a synergistic effect between the plasma and catalysts occurred in the plasma-catalysis system since the plasma alone and the catalytic alone only exhibited a lower removal efficiency at room temperature. The above results were consistent with that obtained by other investigations [14,17,34]. In addition, the effects of initial toluene concentration and residence time on the toluene removal efficiency under the SED of 1500 J/L were also investigated in the plasma-catalysis system coupled with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3, as shown in Fig.S3-S4. The removal efficiency and CO2 selectivity of toluene in the plasma-catalysis system were increased as the decrease of the initial toluene concentration and increase of the residence time. Table 2 summarized the toluene removal performance in the plasma coupled with different catalysts. It can be seen that the plasma coupled with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 exhibited a higher energy efficiency (4.51 g/KWh) compared with other studies [5,14,21,26,34,38]. The toluene removal performance in plasma-catalysis system packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 at different RH was also investigated. Fig. 7 illustrated that the toluene removal decreased from 98.59% to 71.0% when the RH increased from 0% (dry gas) to 75% at the SED of 1500 J/L, indicating that there was a negative effect of RH on the toluene removal due to the suppression of steam on discharge. There were several reasons that caused the above results: one was that the increase in RH caused a reduction of electron energy and suppressed the formation of electronically excited species, inhibiting the conversion of toluene into CO2 [39]. Another was that hydroxyl radicals generated from the steam discharge had a positive effect on the deep oxidation of toluene [40]. The last was that the increase of RH resultd in a decrease of ozone generation since water-related species consumed atomic O, resulted in decreasing of the atomic O and suppressing the ozone generation [41]. Thus the coupling of the above effects resulted in the decrease of the toluene removal. To evaluate the long-term performance of the plasma coupled with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3, a successive experiment for toluene removal was carried out at SED of 1500 J/L, as shown in Fig. 8 . Fig. 8(a) indicated the toluene removal efficiency stabled at 98% and the CO2 selectivity was sustained at 88% in the plasma-catalysis system packed with Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 for the first 10 h. When the steam with the RH of 90% was introduced to the plasma-catalysis system, the removal efficiency and the CO2 selectivity for toluene conversion were respectively decreased to 85% and 67%. After the steam was cut off, the removal efficiency and the CO2 selectivity of toluene returned to 98% and 88%, indicating the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a better self-regeneration and thus keeping the high stability during the toluene removal process [42]. The differences in conversion under different RH can be attributed to the competitive adsorption of H2O with toluene [5,43]. 3.4 Gaseous products identification and formation mechanism analysis In order to understand the toxic by-products of the exhaust gas in the plasma-catalysis system, the composition of gaseous products during toluene removal process was firstly on-line analyzed using FT-IR spectrometer, and FT-IR spectra of the plasma coupled with Mn/γ-Al2O3 and Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 for toluene removal was compared with that treated by the plasma alone, as shown in Fig. 9 . Infrared bands of CO2 (2360 cm−1), benzaldehyde (1730 cm−1), formic acid (1120 cm−1), aromatic CH (3050 cm−1), aliphatic C–H (3030–2750 cm−1), aromatic C = C (1521 cm−1), aromatic C = C (1120 cm−1) and hydroxyls (3740 cm−1) were detected for both plasma alone and plasma coupled with catalysts due to the oxidation of toluene. The O3 (1055 and 2110 cm−1), and NO2 (1755 cm−1) were also observed due to the discharge in air [14]. Moreover, the absorbance intensity of the gaseous products for plasma alone was distinct from that of the plasma coupled with catalysts. The combination of plasma and the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 exhibited a stronger peak of CO2 and hydroxyls, while the bands of benzaldehyde, formic acid, aromatic CH, aliphatic C–H, aromatic C = C and aromatic C = C were weaker compared with that of the plasma alone. The above results indicated that the plasma packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 promoted the further oxidation of intermediates (benzaldehyde, formic acid, aromatic CH, aliphatic C–H, aromatic C = C and aromatic C = C, etc.) into CO2 and H2O [17,38,44], as observed by GC/MS. It was also found that the absorbance intensities of O3 and NOx were greatly reduced when the plasma was packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3, indicating that the formation of toxic by-products during toluene removal was effectively suppressed by the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. To further study the effect of RH on the toxic by-products of the exhaust gas in the plasma-catalysis system, NOx, O3 and organic compounds varied with the reaction time and RH were also measured in the successive toluene removal test, as shown in Fig. 8(b) and Fig. 8(c). It could be seen that the contents of NOx and O3 were stabled at 30–35 ppm and 61–65 ppm in the plasma-catalysis system packed with Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 at RH of 0 for the first 10 h. When the steam with the RH of 90% was introduced to the plasma-catalysis system, the contents of NOx were increased to 50–57 ppm, while the O3 was decreased to 41–45 ppm. After the steam was cut off, the contents of NOx and O3 returned to 34–36 ppm and 65–69 ppm. The increase of RH resultd in a decrease of ozone generation since water-related species consumed atomic O, resulted in decreasing of the atomic O and suppressing the ozone generation, and then caused the decrease of the toluene removal. Fig. 8(c) also indicated that the total organic compounds of these toxic by-products in the successive toluene removal test under the RH of 0%, 90%, 0% were in sequence as 26.79 ppm, 21.39 ppm and 25.65 ppm. The organic compounds of these toxic by-products comprised aliphatic, aromatics, oxygenated hydrocarbon, as listed in Tab.S1. The toluene destruction pathway in the plasma-catalysis system based on the identified intermediates was also proposed, as shown in Fig. 10 . Generally, the VOCs removal by plasma-catalysis consisted of three pathways including impact by energetic electrons, attack by gas-phase radicals (such as O atom and OH•) and deep oxidation by active oxygen species over the catalyst surface [38]. Considering the reaction rate constants together with concentration of energetic electrons and gas-phase radicals, toluene has higher chances to be destructed by the energetic electrons in plasma-catalysis system [45]. Thus, H-abstraction from the methyl group by energetic electrons is the primary pathway of toluene destruction since C–H in the methyl group has the lowest dissociation energy of 3.7 eV [46]. The H-abstraction from the methyl group in benzene-ring by energetic electrons would form a benzyl radical which would react with O atom or OH• to form benzaldehyde, and then the benzaldehyde could be further oxidized into benzoic acid, as analyzed by GC–MS. Furthermore, C–C between methyl and benzene ring also can be easily destructed by energetic electrons, generating phenyl radical and methyl [34]. The phenyl radical could react with excited H• and CH3• to form benzene, o/m/p-xylene, ethylbenzene, etc., which were also identified by GC–MS. Meanwhile, the ring-containing intermediate products could couple to form naphthalene. The benzene ring in those aromatic intermediates may be further attacked by energetic electrons to generate chain intermediates such as alkanes and alkanes, and then these chain intermediates are oxidized to CO2 and H2O [47]. Besides of energetic electrons impact, gas-phase radicals attack is another important mechanism resulting in toluene destruction during plasma-catalysis process [47]. The H-abstraction from the methyl group in benzene-ring reacted with O/OH• would generate benzaldehyde and benzoic acid. The aromatic intermediates attacked by O/OH• would also cause the direct cleavage of the aromatic ring to generate small molecular substances, such as ethylacetate, acrolein, acetone, and methylethylketone, and then undergo a series of oxidation step by O/OH• attack, resulting in the formation of CO2 and H2O [48]. In addition, active oxygen species were formed on the surface of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst through the redox reaction between Mn and Fe species (Mn4+ + Fe2+= Fe3+ + Mn3+), which would also convert the residual toluene and intermediates into CO2 and H2O [4,22]. Meanwhile, it was also found that the main composition of the organic compounds under the RH of 0% was ethylacetate, which accounted for 95% of the total organic compounds. However, the toluene, ethylbenzene, m/p-xylene, o-xylene, and styrene were the main species in these organic compounds of the toxic by-products when the RH was changed to 90% in the successive toluene removal test. There were two reasons that caused the above results. One is that the reactions between electrons and water were faster than that between electrons and oxygen since the rate coefficients of reactions between electrons and water are higher than that of reactions between electrons and oxygen [39,46]. Therefore, the presence of steam inevitably changes the electrical characteristics and emission characteristics of plasma, which may attenuate the effect of energetic electrons. Another is primarily that the active species in the plasma is quenched by the steam due to the competitive adsorption between steam and toluene on the catalyst surfaces [46]. To further quantitatively measure the toxic by-products in the exhaust gas, an ozone monitor and a NOx analyzer were respectively used to detect the O3 and NOx, as shown in Fig. 11 . The contents of O3 and NOx treated by the plasma alone were higher than that of the plasma coupled with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 at all SED. The contents of O3 and NOx at SED of 1500 J/L with plasma alone were as high as 365 and 95 ppm, while the O3 and NOx contents dramatically reduced to 56 and 32 ppm when the plasma packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3. Feng et al. [30]. observed that the NOx content at SED of 300 J/L was above 300 ppm in a plasma packed with Mn2Ox catalyst for toluene removal. Bo et al. [49]. found that the O3 content at SED of 180 J/L was as high as 164 ppm, and NOx content at SED of 400 J/L was 70 ppm in a plasma packed with Mn3O4/VG catalyst for toluene removal. Chang et al. [40]. found that the contents of O3 and NOx at SED of 300 J/L were 400 and 300 ppm in a plasma coupled with MnCo catalyst for toluene removal. 3.5 Comparison of used and fresh catalysts In order to discovery the variation of the physico-chemical properties of used Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, the used (a successive toluene removal test for 24 h at SED of 1500 J/L) and the fresh Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst were tested by the BET, XPS and TG, as shown in Table 3 and Fig.S5-S7. Table 3 revealed that the BET surface areas, pore volume and pore size were respectively reduced from 348.8 to 155.3 m2/g, from 0.49 to 0.44 cm3/g and from 10.6 to 7.2 nm, indicating that the plasma may broke the pore structure of the catalyst or formed some coke deposition over the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [26,34]. XPS results revealed that the content of Fe3+ in the used Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 increased since the Fe2+ species were oxidized into Fe3+, and the lattice oxygen was increased due to interaction between Mn and Fe, and synergistic effect between plasma and catalyst, while the Mn 2p XPS spectra were varied slightly after underwent plasma-catalytic test, revealing that the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 was stable. This result suggested that the active sites in Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can be completely regenerated by the plasma-catalysis system [3,22]. The redox reaction between Mn and Fe species (Mn4+ + Fe2+= Fe3+ + Mn3+) took place on the surface of the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, which reduced the energy that consumed for the electron transfer and oxygen mobility, which was beneficial to improve the reducibility of the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The toluene and intermediates adsorbed on the surface of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalysts can react with oxygen vacancies [10,22]. Meanwhile, the oxygen vacancies in the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can be supplemented from ozone decomposition [14]. It was also observed that the binding energies of Fe, Mn and absorbed oxygen species of the used catalyst shifted slightly to higher values compared with the fresh one (Fig. S7), probably due to the intermediates species strongly adsorbed on the active site of catalyst, and then formed some coke deposition [8,28]. TG-DTG technique was employed to understand the coke deposition on the surface of the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalysts during the plasma-catalysis reaction, as shown in Fig. 12 . A weight loss of 14.37% occurred at 120−650 °C, which was contributed to the coke oxidation, indicating that the coke deposition was formed with the rate of 0.57%•h − 1 in the plasma-catalysis reaction. 3.6 Kinetic of toluene removal by the plasma-catalysis system The VOCs removal has been reported following the pseudo-first-order model during plasma-catalysis process [15]. In the plasma-catalysis system, the toluene removal mechanism consisted of gas phase reaction and surface reaction [18]. One was that the electrons or gas phase radicals (such as O and OH) directly reacted with gas phase toluene molecules. Another was that the adsorbed toluene or intermediates on the surface of catalysts reacted with reactive species (O and OH). Thus, the removal rate of the toluene can be expressed as Eq. Taking the logarithm of the Eq. (11) to obtain the Eq. (12); where C0 is the toluene initial content: (12) − ln c c 0 = k s t Meanwhile, the toluene removal efficiency is defined as: (13) η = 1 − c c 0 Substituting of Eq. (13) into Eq. (12), and the kinetic model can be expressed as Eq. (14): (14) − ln ( 1 − η ) = k s t Finally, the correlation of versus 1/T can be obtained from the Arrhenius equation, as Eq.(15). (15) ln [ − ln ( 1 − η ) ] = ln A − E a R T Where, A is the pre-exponential factor, 1/s; Ea is the apparent activation energy, kJ mol–1; R is the gas constant, 8.314 J (mol K)–1. Therefore, the apparent activation energy Ea could be obtained based on the correlation of versus 1/T. The pseudo-first-order kinetic model of toluene removal under different catalysts is shown in Fig. 13 . The relationship between -ln(1-η) and t indicated that the toluene removal by the plasma coupled with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are all well-fitted to the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, indicating that the pseudo-first-order kinetic model can be used to well describe the toluene removal in a plasma coupled with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 reactor. Meanwhile, it also can be found that the reaction rate constant is significantly affected by the Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The correlation of reaction rate constant versus SED for the toluene removal is presented in Fig. 14 . It can be seen that the reaction rate of toluene removal is 0.00168 s − 1. To verify the reliability of the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, the calculated value and the experimental data for the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are compared in Fig. 15 . The results demonstrated that the toluene removal efficiency of the calculated values are well consistent with that of the experimental data. The correlations of versus 1/T are shown in Fig. 16 and Table 4 . The apparent activation energy of toluene removal in the plasma-catalytic system under different catalysts followed in the order of Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 < Fe2 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 < Fe1 −Mn2/γ-Al2O3 < Fe1 −Mn3/γ-Al2O3 < Fe3 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 < Mn/γ-Al2O3 < Fe/γ-Al2O3< plasma alone, indicating that the plasma packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 exhibited a higher reaction rate for toluene removal, proved by the toluene removal activity in the plasma-catalysis system. 4 Conclusion A series of Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by reflux-coprecipitation method. The catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, SEM and TEM, and then the toluene removal in a nonthermal plasma-catalytic system packed with these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalyst were studied. Meanwhile, the effects of initial toluene concentration, residence time and relative humidity on the toluene removal efficiency and secondary pollutants were investigated, and the reaction kinetic and reaction route were obtained during toluene removal in a plasma-catalysis reactor. Compared with the non-thermal plasma, the removal efficiency and CO2 selectivity were greatly increased and the secondary pollutants and activation energy were significantly reduced during toluene removal in a nonthermal plasma coupled with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The kinetic results indicated that the toluene removal in a nonthermal plasma packed with these Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were well-fitted to the pseudo-first-order kinetic model. Meanwhile, the plasma packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/Al2O3 exhibited the highest removal efficiency (98.59%) and CO2 selectivity (88.02%) with the lowest secondary pollutants and activation energy under condition of the SED of 1500 J/L and the GHSV of 80,000 ml g − 1 h − 1. There were three reasons caused the above phenomena. Firstly, the Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3 possessed a higher BET surface area and pore volume, which was conducive to the adsorption and transformation of toluene on the surface of the catalyst. Secondly, a strong interaction between Fe and Mn improved the dispersion of active components and increased the contents of Fe3+, Mn4+ and lattice oxygen, and then enhanced the electron transfer rate, benefiting for further oxidation of toluene and its intermediates into CO2 and H2O. Lastly, a synergistic effect between the plasma and catalysts significantly improved toluene removal activity and reduced the O3 and NO x generation in the plasma-catalysis system. coredata.dc:description: In this study, Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were synthesized by reflux-coprecipitation method, and then these catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, SEM and TEM. Meanwhile, the toluene removal and secondary pollutants in a nonthermal plasma coupled with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 reactor were studied, and then the reaction kinetic model and reaction pathway for the toluene removal were proposed. The results indicated that positive synergistic effect between the plasma and Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalysts greatly improved the removal performance, and reduced secondary pollutants and activation energy during toluene removal process in the plasma packed with Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 system. Meanwhile, the plasma packed with the Fe1 −Mn1/Al2O3 exhibited the highest removal efficiency (98.59%) and CO2 selectivity (88.02%) with the lowest secondary pollutants and activation energy during toluene removal under the SED of 1500 J/L and the GHSV of 80,000 ml g − 1 h − 1. Finally, the toluene removal pathway in the plasma-catalysis system was also discussed based on the identified intermediates and synergistic effect between the plasma and Fe1 −Mn1/γ-Al2O3.
coredata.dc:title: Refluxing-coprecipitation to synthesize Fex −Mny/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for toluene removal in a nonthermal plasma-catalysis reactor
